#REDIRECT [[Murders of Channon Christian and Christopher Newsom]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Christian, Channon}} [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:American torture victims]] [[Category:Murdered American students]] [[Category:People murdered in Tennessee]] [[Category:Deaths by person]] [[Category:University of Tennessee alumni]] [[Category:People from Louisiana]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category:People from Nacogdoches, Texas]] [[Category:Farragut High School alumni]]

{{short description|An organisation of individuals who claim to share a common concern for the future of humanity and strive to make a difference.}} {{primary sources|date=December 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox organization | name = The Club of Rome | logo = Club of Rome Logo.svg | logo_size = 220px | type = [[Non-profit organisation|Non-profit]]
[[Non-governmental organisation|NGO]] | founded = 1968 by [[Aurelio Peccei]], [[David Rockefeller]] and [[Alexander King (scientist)|Alexander King]]
Co- Presidents: [[Anders Wijkman]] and [[Ernst Ulrich von Weizsäcker]]
Secretary General: [[Graeme Maxton]] | location = [[Winterthur]], [[Canton Zurich]], [[Switzerland]] | fields = [[Global warming]], [[Well-being]], [[Humanitarian]] challenges | homepage = {{URL|http://www.clubofrome.org/}} }} The '''Club of Rome''' describes itself as "an organisation of individuals who share a common concern for the future of humanity and strive to make a difference. Our mission is to promote understanding of the global challenges facing humanity and to propose solutions through scientific analysis, communication and advocacy."{{cite web|title=Home|url=https://www.clubofrome.org/|website=Club of Rome|accessdate=29 November 2017}} Founded in 1968 at [[Accademia dei Lincei]] in [[Rome]], [[Italy]], the Club of Rome consists of current and former heads of state, UN bureaucrats, high-level politicians and government officials, diplomats, scientists, economists, and business leaders from around the globe.{{cite web|url=http://www.green-agenda.com/globalrevolution.html |title=The First Global Revolution |publisher=The Green Agenda|date=19 November 2005|accessdate=6 December 2012}} It stimulated considerable public attention in 1972 with the first report to the Club of Rome, ''[[The Limits to Growth]]''. Since 1 July 2008 the organization has been based in [[Winterthur]], Switzerland. == Formation == The Club of Rome was founded in April 1968 by [[Aurelio Peccei]], an Italian industrialist, and [[Alexander King (scientist)|Alexander King]], a Scottish [[scientist]]. It was formed when a small international group of people from the fields of academia, civil society, diplomacy, and industry met at [[Villa Farnesina]] in [[Rome]], hence the name.{{cite web|title=History: 1968|url=https://www.clubofrome.org/about-us/history/|website=Club of Rome|accessdate=29 November 2017}} ==The ''problématique''== Central to the formation of the club was Peccei's concept of the ''problematic''. It was his opinion that viewing the problems of mankind—environmental deterioration, poverty, endemic ill-health, urban blight, criminality—individually, in isolation or as "problems capable of being solved in their own terms", was doomed to failure. All are interrelated. "It is this generalized meta-problem (or [[meta-system]] of problems) which we have called and shall continue to call the "problematic" that inheres in our situation."{{cite web |url=http://sunsite.utk.edu/FINS/loversofdemocracy/Predicament.PTI.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203125912/http://sunsite.utk.edu/FINS/loversofdemocracy/Predicament.PTI.pdf |archivedate=3 February 2014 |date=1970 |title=The Predicament of Mankind |accessdate=13 May 2016}}{{RP|12-13}} In 1970, Peccei's vision was laid out in a document written by [[Hasan Özbekhan]], [[Erich Jantsch]], and [[Alexander Christakis]]. Entitled, ''The Predicament of Mankind; Quest for Structured Responses to Growing Worldwide Complexities and Uncertainties: A PROPOSAL''. The document would serve as the roadmap for the ''[[The Limits to Growth|LTG]]'' project. ==''The Limits to Growth''== The Club of Rome stimulated considerable public attention with the first report to the club, ''[[The Limits to Growth]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.clubofrome.org/docs/confs/meadows_abstract_21_08_04.pdf |title=30-Year Update of Limits to Growth finds global society in "Overshoot," Foresees social, economic, and environmental decline |last= |first= |date= |website=Club of Rome |publisher= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517054744/http://www.clubofrome.org/docs/confs/meadows_abstract_21_08_04.pdf |archive-date=17 May 2008 |access-date=30 September 2016 |last1=Meadows |first1=Dennis |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Published in 1972, its computer simulations suggested that [[economic growth]] could not continue indefinitely because of resource depletion. The [[1973 oil crisis]] increased public concern about this problem. The report went on to sell 30 million copies in more than 30 languages, making it the best-selling environmental book in history.{{cite web|last1=Simmons|first1=Matthew R.|title=Revisiting The Limits to Growth: Could the Club of Rome Have Been Correct After All?|url=http://www.mudcitypress.com/PDF/clubofrome.pdf|website=Mud City Press|accessdate=29 November 2017|date=October 2000}} Even before ''The Limits to Growth'' was published, [[Eduard Pestel]] and [[Mihajlo Mesarovic]] of [[Case Western Reserve University]] had begun work on a far more elaborate model (it distinguished ten world regions and involved 200,000 equations compared with 1,000 in the Meadows model). The research had the full support of the club and its final publication, ''Mankind at the Turning Point'' was accepted as the official "second report" to the Club of Rome in 1974.{{cite book|last1=Mersarovic|first1=Mihajlo|last2=Pestel|first2=Eduard|title=Mankind at the Turning Point|date=1975|publisher=Hutchinson|url=https://www.clubofrome.org/report/mankind-at-the-turning-point/|isbn=0-09-123471-9}} In addition to providing a more refined regional breakdown, Pestel and Mesarovic had succeeded in integrating social as well as technical data. The second report revised the scenarios of the original ''Limits to Growth'' and gave a more optimistic prognosis for the future of the environment, noting that many of the factors involved were within human control and therefore that environmental and economic catastrophe were preventable or avoidable. In 1991, the club published ''[[The First Global Revolution]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/2297152/Alexander-King-Bertrand-Schneider-The-First-Global-Revolution-Club-of-Rome-1993-Edition|title=The First Global Revolution (Club of Rome) 1993 Edition|publisher=Scribd.|date=17 March 2008|accessdate=6 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026053527/http://www.scribd.com/doc/2297152/Alexander-King-Bertrand-Schneider-The-First-Global-Revolution-Club-of-Rome-1993-Edition|archivedate=26 October 2012|df=dmy-all}} It analyses the problems of humanity, calling these collectively or in essence the "problematique". It notes that, historically, social or political unity has commonly been motivated by enemies in common: "The need for enemies seems to be a common historical factor. Some states have striven to overcome domestic failure and internal contradictions by blaming external enemies. The ploy of finding a scapegoat is as old as mankind itself—when things become too difficult at home, divert attention to adventure abroad. Bring the divided nation together to face an outside enemy, either a real one, or else one invented for the purpose. With the disappearance of the traditional enemy, the temptation is to use religious or ethnic minorities as scapegoats, especially those whose differences from the majority are disturbing."Alexander King & Bertrand Schneider. ''The First Global Revolution'' (The Club of Rome), 1993. p. 70 "Every state has been so used to classifying its neighbours as friend or foe, that the sudden absence of traditional adversaries has left governments and public opinion with a great void to fill. New enemies have to be identified, new strategies imagined, and new weapons devised." "In searching for a common enemy against whom we can unite, we came up with the idea that pollution, the threat of global warming, water shortages, famine and the like, would fit the bill. In their totality and their interactions these phenomena do constitute a common threat which must be confronted by everyone together. But in designating these dangers as the enemy, we fall into the trap, which we have already warned readers about, namely mistaking symptoms for causes. All these dangers are caused by human intervention in natural processes, and it is only through changed attitudes and behaviour that they can be overcome. The real enemy then is humanity itself."King & Schneider, p. 115 In 2001 the Club of Rome established a [[think tank]], called ''tt30'', consisting of about 30 men and women, ages 25–35. It aimed to identify and solve problems in the world, from the perspective of youth.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} A study by Graham Turner of the research organisation [[CSIRO]] in Australia in 2008 found that "30 years of historical data compare favorably with key features of a business-as-usual scenario called the "standard run" scenario, which results in collapse of the global system midway through the 21st century."{{cite journal| url=http://graduateinstitute.ch/files/live/sites/iheid/files/sites/political_science/users/elena.gadjanova/public/Issues%20in%20Env%20Politics%202010/Turner%202008.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140913032823/http://graduateinstitute.ch/files/live/sites/iheid/files/sites/political_science/users/elena.gadjanova/public/Issues%20in%20Env%20Politics%202010/Turner%202008.pdf |archivedate=13 September 2014|title=A comparison of The Limits to Growth with 30 years of reality|journal=[[Global Environmental Change]] |volume=18 |pages=397–411 |first=Graham M. |last=Turner |year=2008 |accessdate=13 May 2016}} == Organization == According to its website, the Club of Rome is composed of "scientists, economists, businessmen, international high civil servants, heads of state and former heads of state from all five continents who are convinced that the future of humankind is not determined once and for all and that each human being can contribute to the improvement of our societies." The Club of Rome is a membership organization and has different membership categories.{{cite web|title=Membership|url=https://www.clubofrome.org/membership/|website=Club of Rome|accessdate=29 November 2017}} Full members engage in the research activities, projects, and contribute to decision-making processes during the Club's annual general assembly. Of the full members, 12 are elected to form the executive committee, which sets the general direction and the agenda.{{cite web|title=Executive Committee|url=https://www.clubofrome.org/members-groups/executive-committee/|website=Club of Rome|accessdate=29 November 2017}} Of the executive committee, two are elected as co-presidents and two as vice-presidents. The secretary-general is elected from the members of the executive committee. The secretary-general is responsible for the day-to-day operation of the club from its headquarters in Winterthur, Switzerland. Aside from full members there are associate members, who participate in research and projects, but have no vote in the general assembly.{{cite web|title=Associate Members|url=https://www.clubofrome.org/members-groups/associate-members/|website=Club of Rome|accessdate=29 November 2017}} The club also has honorary members. Notable honorary members include [[Beatrix of the Netherlands|Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands]], [[Orio Giarini]], [[Fernando Henrique Cardoso]], [[Mikhail Gorbachev]], King [[Juan Carlos I of Spain]], [[Horst Köhler]], and [[Manmohan Singh]].{{cite web|title=Honorary Members|url=https://www.clubofrome.org/members-groups/honorary-members/|website=Club of Rome|accessdate=29 November 2017}} The annual general assembly of 2016 took place in Berlin on 10–11 November. Among the guest speakers were former German President [[Christian Wulff]], German Minister for Economic Cooperation and Development [[Gerd Müller (politician)|Gerd Müller]], as well as Nobel Laureate [[Muhammad Yunus]]. ==National associations== The Club has national associations in 35 countries and territories.{{cite web|title=National Associations|url=https://www.clubofrome.org/about-us/national-associations/|website=Club of Rome|accessdate=29 November 2017}} The mission of the national associations is to spread the ideas and vision in their respective countries, to offer solutions and to lobby for a more sustainable and just economy in their nations, and to support the international secretariat of the Club with the organization of events, such as the annual general assembly.{{cite web|title=Annual Conference 2016|url=https://www.clubofrome.org/event/annual-conference-2016/|website=The Club of Rome|accessdate=26 January 2018}} ==Current activities== {{Asof|2017}} there have been 43 reports to the club.{{cite web|title=Reports|url=https://www.clubofrome.org/activities/reports/|website=Club of Rome|accessdate=5 December 2017}} These are peer-reviewed studies commissioned by the executive committee, or suggested by a member or group of members, or by outside individuals and institutions. The most recent is ''Come On! Capitalism, Short-termism, Population and the Destruction of the Planet''.{{cite book|last1=von Weizsaecker|first1=Ernst|last2=Wijkman|first2=Anders|title=Come On! Capitalism, Short-termism, Population and the Destruction of the Planet|date=2018|publisher=Springer|location=New York|isbn=978-1-4939-7418-4|doi=10.1007/978-1-4939-7419-1|url=https://www.springer.com/de/book/9781493974184#aboutAuthors|accessdate=29 November 2017}} In 2016, the club initiated a new youth project called "Reclaim Economics". With this project they support students, activists, intellectuals, artists, video-makers, teachers, professors and others to shift the teaching of economics away from the mathematical pseudo-science it has become.{{cite web|title=Reclaim Economics| url=https://www.clubofrome.org/project/reclaimeconomics/|website=Club of Rome|accessdate=29 November 2017}} ==Critics== Nobel prize-winning economist [[Robert Solow]] criticized ''The Limits to Growth'' as having "simplistic" scenarios. He has also been a vocal critic of the Club of Rome, ostensibly for amateurism. He has said that, "The one thing that really annoys me is amateurs making absurd statements about economics, and I thought that the Club of Rome was nonsense. Not because natural resources or environmental necessities might not at some time pose a limit, not on growth, but on the level of economic activity—I didn't think that was a nonsensical idea—but because the Club of Rome was doing amateur dynamics without a license, without a proper qualification. And they were doing it badly, so I got steamed up about that."{{cite web|last1=Clement|first1=Douglas|title=Interview with Robert Solow|url=https://www.minneapolisfed.org/publications/the-region/interview-with-robert-solow|website=Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis|accessdate=29 November 2017|date=1 September 2002}} An analysis of the world model used for ''The Limits to Growth'' by mathematicians Vermeulens and Jongh shown it to be "very sensitive to small parameter variations" and having "dubious assumptions and approximations". {{cite journal |last1= Vermeulen |first1= P.J. |last2= De Jongh |first2= D.C.J. |date= 29 June 1976 |title= Parameter sensitivity of the ‘Limits to Growth’ world model |url= https://doi.org/10.1016/0307-904X(76)90021-4 |journal= Applied Mathematical Modelling |volume= 1 |issue= 1 |pages= 29-32 |doi= 10.1016/0307-904X(76)90021-4 |access-date= 2018-07-23 |name-list-format=vanc }} An interdisciplinary team at Sussex University's Science Policy Research Unit reviewed the structure and assumptions of the models used and published its finding in ''Models of Doom''; showing that the forecasts of the world's future are very sensitive to a few unduly pessimistic key assumptions. The Sussex scientists also claim that the Meadows et Al. methods, data, and predictions are faulty, that their world models (and their Malthusian bias) do not accurately reflect reality. {{cite book |last= Cole |first= H.S.D. |date= 1973 |title= Models of doom; a critique of The limits to growth |url= https://openlibrary.org/books/OL5312431M/Models_of_doom |location= USA |publisher= Universe Books |page= 244 p., illus. |isbn= 0876631847}} ==Notable members== * [[Hans-Peter Dürr]] (1929–2014) * [[Mahdi Elmandjra]] (1933-2014) * [[Călin Georgescu]] (born in 1962) - Chairman of the [[Board of directors|Board]], ''European Support Centre for the Club of Rome'', now ''European Research Center'', [[Vienna]] and [[Konstanz]] (2010-) * [[Nicholas Georgescu-Roegen]] (1906–1994), economist, author of ''The Entropy Law and the Economic Process'' * [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] (born in 1931), last leader of the Soviet Union * [[Dzhermen Gvishiani]], son in law of [[Alexei Kosygin]] * [[Václav Havel]] (1936–2011), last president of Czechoslovakia, first president of the Czech Republic * [[Bohdan Hawrylyshyn]] (1926–2016) – Chairman International Management Institute – Kyiv ([[:uk:IMI-Kyiv]]), Honorary Council of Ukraine * [[Daisaku Ikeda]] * [[Mugur Isărescu]] (born in 1949), the Governor of the [[National Bank of Romania]] in [[Bucharest]] * [[Erich Jantsch]], author of ''Technological Forecasting'' (1929–1980) * [[Derrick de Kerckhove]] (born 1944) * [[Alexander King (scientist)|Alexander King]] (1909–2007) founding member{{cite web|title=The story of the Club of Rome |url=http://www.clubofrome.org/?p=375 |publisher=Club of Rome |accessdate=27 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531074559/http://www.clubofrome.org/?p=375 |archivedate=31 May 2013 |df=dmy }} * [[Max Kohnstamm]] ([[Netherlands]]), former Secretary General of the [[European Coal and Steel Community|ECSC]] (1914–2010) * [[David Korten]] * [[Elisabeth Mann-Borgese]] - first female member since 1970 * [[Graeme Maxton]] * [[Dennis Meadows]] (born 1942) * [[Donella Meadows]] (1941–2001) * [[Mihajlo D. Mesarovic]] * [[George P. Mitchell]] (1919–2013) * [[Mohan Munasinghe]] * [[Aurelio Peccei]] (1908–1984) founding member * [[John R. Platt]] (1918–1992) * [[Mamphela Ramphele]] * [[Joseph Stiglitz]] (born 1943), Nobel prize-winning economist * [[Ivo Šlaus]] * [[Prince Hassan bin Talal]] * [[Hugo Thiemann]] (1917–2012) * [[Pierre Elliott Trudeau]] (1919–2000), former prime minister of [[Canada]]; * [[Robert Uffen]] (1923–2009) * [[Victor Urquidi]] (1919–2014) * [[Frederic Vester]] (1925–2003) * [[Ashok Khosla]] * [[Fernando Henrique Cardoso]] == See also == {{div col|colwidth=18em}} * [[Club of Budapest]] * [[Club of Madrid]] * [[Club of Vienna]] * [[Futures studies]] * [[Harlan Cleveland]] - [[DIKW]] * [[Olduvai theory]] * [[Peak Oil]] * [[Survivalism]] * [[The Revenge of Gaia]] * [[The First Global Revolution]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [http://www.lastcallthefilm.org/ Last Call], documentary about ''The Limits to Growth'' ([[Trailer (promotion)|trailer]]) * [http://www.laetusinpraesens.org/links/clubrome.php Club of Rome Reports and Bifurcations, a 40-year overview] 17 March 2010 / Draft * [http://www.abc.net.au/science/slab/rome/default.htm Analysis of ''Limits to Growth'' by Australian Broadcasting Corporation from 1999] * [http://www.donellameadows.org/ Donella Meadows Institute] * Suter, K. (1999). "The Club of Rome: The Global Conscience". ''Contemporary Review'', 275 (1602), 1–5 {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Club of Rome}} [[Category:1968 establishments in Italy]] [[Category:Think tanks established in 1968]] [[Category:20th century in Rome]] [[Category:Futurology]] [[Category:Globalism]] [[Category:Oceanography]] [[Category:Political and economic think tanks based in Europe]] [[Category:International sustainability organizations]] [[Category:Systems thinking]] [[Category:Think tanks based in Italy]] [[Category:Winterthur]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Blair Peach | image = Blair Peach.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Clement Blair Peach | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1946|03|25}} | birth_place = [[New Zealand]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1979|04|23|1946|03|25|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Southall]], London, England | death_cause = Head trauma | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = Death during [[Anti-Nazi League]] demonstration | occupation = Teacher }}
'''Clement Blair Peach''' (25 March 1946 – 23 April 1979) was a New Zealand-born teacher who died during an anti-racism demonstration in Southall, Middlesex, England.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/apr/30/cass-report-blair-peach-justice | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=For Blair Peach, a little justice | first=Celia | last=Stubbs | date=30 April 2010}}</ref> A campaigner and activist against the [[far right]], in April 1979 Peach took part in an [[Anti-Nazi League]] demonstration in [[Southall]] against a [[British National Front|National Front]] election meeting in the town hall and was knocked unconscious.
He died the next day in hospital from head injuries that he sustained. An inquest jury returned a verdict of [[death by misadventure]] in May 1980. Peach's girlfriend, Celia Stubbs, continued to campaign for many years for a public inquiry into his death. The [[Metropolitan Police Service]] reached an out-of-court settlement in 1989 with Peach's brother.<ref name=BBCApril13/> The Metropolitan Police reports into the death of Blair Peach, identifying the probable responsibility of one of their own officers, were made available to the public on 27 April 2010.<ref name="met">[http://www.met.police.uk/foi/units/blair_peach.htm Investigation into the death of Blair Peach] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100502005706/http://www.met.police.uk/foi/units/blair_peach.htm |date=2 May 2010 }} Metropolitan Police Service, 27 April 2010</ref>
== Life == Peach was born in New Zealand. He studied at [[Victoria University of Wellington]] and was for a time co-editor of the ''Argot'' literary magazine with his flatmates [[Dennis List]] and David Rutherford. He worked as a fireman and as a hospital orderly in New Zealand before moving to London in 1969. He became a teacher at the Phoenix School in [[Bow, London|Bow]], East London, a [[special needs]] school, working there from 1969 until his death 10 years later.<ref name=irr>[http://www.irr.org.uk/2009/april/bw000024.html Remembering Blair Peach: 30 years on] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100429142146/http://www.irr.org.uk/2009/april/bw000024.html |date=29 April 2010 }}, Chris Searle, Institute of Race Relations. 23 April 2009</ref> At the time of his death he was an active member of the Socialist Teachers' Association within the [[National Union of Teachers]], and a member of the [[Socialist Workers Party (UK)|Socialist Workers' Party]].<ref name="ms20140423">{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=The death of Blair Peach: Remembering a day of infamy |url=http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/a-aaf2-The-death-of-Blair-Peach-Remembering-a-day-of-infamy |newspaper=Morning Star |location=<!-- no location --> |date=23 April 2014 |access-date=17 June 2016 }}</ref>
==Activism and death== Peach was an active member of the East London Teachers' Association, a branch of the [[National Union of Teachers]], and became its president in the last year of his life.<ref name=irr/> In 1974, he was charged with threatening behaviour after challenging a local publican's refusal to serve black customers, but acquitted.<ref name=irr/>
Peach became a campaigner and activist against far right and [[neo-Nazi]] organisations. He attended a demonstration held by the [[Anti-Nazi League]] outside the town hall in Southall on Monday 23 April 1979, [[St George's Day]], joining 3,000 protesters against a National Front meeting taking place in the town hall, in the run-up to the [[United Kingdom general election, 1979|1979 general election]]. Present at the demonstration were over 2,500 police, and became violent; more than 40 people, including 21 police, were injured and 300 were arrested.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8119212.stm Blair Peach: A 30-year campaign], BBC News, 25 June 2009</ref> Peach was knocked unconscious in a side street, at the junction of Beachcroft Avenue and Orchard Avenue ({{coord|51.51051|N|0.38034|W|type:event_region:GB_dim:50|display=inline}}), and died the next day in [[Ealing Hospital NHS Trust|Ealing Hospital]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/april/23/newsid_2523000/2523959.stm 1979: Teacher dies in Southall race riots] BBC On This Day, 23 April.</ref> Another demonstrator, Clarence Baker, a singer of the reggae band [[Misty in Roots]], remained in a coma for five months.<ref>[http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=17687 Blair Peach: Killed By Police], ''Socialist Worker'', 21 April 2009</ref>
===Subsequent, widespread protests===
{{Quote box|width=300px|align=right|quote=I understand the concern of your people. But if you keep off the streets of London and behave yourselves you won't have the SPG to worry about. | source= ~[[David McNee|Sir David McNee]], then [[Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis|Commissioner]] of the [[Metropolitan Police Service]], defending the actions of the SPG to a black journalist.<ref name="Celia Stubbs The Guardian"/>}} Days after Peach's death, 10,000 marched past the place where he collapsed. The now-demolished Dominion Cinema, Southall, where his body was lying in repose, was visited by 8,000 [[Sikhs]] on the eve of Peach's funeral.<ref name="Celia Stubbs The Guardian">{{cite news|author=Paul Lewis |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/jun/12/blair-peach-police-investigation-death |title=Partner of man killed by Met officers calls for investigation to be made public|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=13 June 2009 |accessdate=3 March 2010 | location=London}}</ref> 10,000 people attended his funeral, which took place 51 days after 23 April.<ref name="Celia Stubbs The Guardian"/> Public reaction to Peach's death, and other underlying racial tensions including excessive police use of the [[Sus law]], ultimately led to the [[1981 Brixton riot]] and a public inquiry by [[Lord Scarman]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/london/content/articles/2009/04/28/southall_rising_feature.shtml Southall Rising], BBC London.</ref>
==The Cass Report and inquest== {{Quote box|width=300px|align=right|quote=I am of the opinion that if a person remains part of a crowd who are throwing missiles, that is collective support and guilt by presence|source= ~John Cass, Commander of the [[Metropolitan Police Service]].<ref name="met"/>}} A team of 30 detectives from the [[Metropolitan Police]], headed by Commander John Cass, conducted an internal investigation of Peach's death. The pathologist's report indicated that Peach's broken skull was not the result of being struck by a truncheon, and he suggested Peach may have been struck by a lead weighted rubber cosh or hosepipe filled with lead shot; unauthorised weapons.<ref name="Celia Stubbs The Guardian"/> Cass' investigation of the Met's [[Special Patrol Group]] (SPG) headquarters unearthed a hoard of unauthorised weapons, including various illegal truncheons and knives, two crowbars, a whip, a 3 ft wooden stave, and a lead-weighted leather stick.<ref name="Celia Stubbs The Guardian"/> An officer was discovered attempting to dispose of a metal cosh; however, it was proven not to be the weapon that killed Peach.<ref name="Celia Stubbs The Guardian"/> Another officer was discovered to be a Nazi supporter.<ref name="Celia Stubbs The Guardian"/> It was also uncovered that one officer present at the riots, who was clean shaven on 23 April, decided to grow a beard,<ref name="Martin Evans The Telegraph"/> whilst another shaved off his moustache which he had sported on 23 April, the day of Peach's death.<ref name="Celia Stubbs The Guardian2">{{cite news|author=Celia Stubbs |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/jun/14/blair-peach-killing-cover-up?showAllComments=true |title=Lessons from the death of Blair Peach |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=14 June 2009 |accessdate=3 March 2010 | location=London}}</ref> Another officer refused to participate in an identity parade,<ref name="Celia Stubbs The Guardian2"/> and all the police officers' uniforms had been dry cleaned before they were to be inspected.<ref name="Celia Stubbs The Guardian2"/>
Cass' reports were leaked and it was reported that he had narrowed down the suspects to six SPG officers, one of whom he believed to have killed Peach.<ref name="Celia Stubbs The Guardian"/> It was claimed by activists that the coroner, Doctor John Burton, dismissed reports that Peach was killed by an officer even before the inquest had finished.<ref name="John Burton The Guardian">{{cite news|author=Paul Lewis |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/jan/22/blair-peach-coroner-inquest |title=Secret document which implicated Blair Peach coroner withheld by Home Office|publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=22 January 2010 |accessdate=3 March 2010 | location=London}}</ref>
===Coroner's inquest===
The coroner decided to refuse to let any of the details from the Cass Report be submitted as evidence.<ref name="BBC-1">{{cite news|author=|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8119212.stm |title= Blair Peach: A 30-year campaign|publisher=BBC |date=25 June 2009 |accessdate=3 March 2010}}</ref> Burton then wrote various letters to the Home Secretary, Lord Chancellor and Attorney General, attacking what he believed to be a well organised fabrication being spread about the death of Peach. The letters accused media organisations such as the [[BBC]] for promoting "biased propaganda".<ref name="John Burton The Guardian"/> He continued by pouring scorn onto the witnesses statements, stating that some were biased as they were "totally politically committed to the [[Socialist Workers Party (Britain)|Socialist Workers Party]]" and dismissed their evidence as "fabrication".<ref name="John Burton The Guardian"/> He also stated, referencing some of the Sikh witnesses, that they "did not have experience of the English system" to give reliable evidence.<ref name="John Burton The Guardian"/> Burton's behaviour was described by one Home Office official as "extremely irate",<ref name="John Burton The Guardian"/> and he resisted calls for the inquest to have a jury until he was forced by the court of appeal.<ref name="John Burton The Guardian"/> Burton was concerned that the inquest might be hijacked by the "extreme left".<ref name="John Burton The Guardian"/> The inquest jury returned a verdict of death by [[misadventure]] on 27 May 1980, prompting Peach's girlfriend, Celia Stubbs, to claim the police constable who allegedly administered the fatal blows had got off "scot-free".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/27/newsid_3023000/3023595.stm 1980: Peach death was 'misadventure'], BBC On This Day, 27 May.</ref> Eleven witnesses said they had seen members of the SPG hit Peach.<ref name=BBCApril13>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/317775.stm "Blair Peach inquiry ruled out"], BBC News, 13 April 1999.</ref>
After the inquest Burton wrote a large article entitled ''The Blair Peach Inquest - the Unpublished Story'' and attempted to publish it until he was convinced by civil servants that the report would "discredit the impartiality of coroners in general and Dr Burton in particular".<ref name="John Burton The Guardian"/>
===2010 Cass report publication===
In June 2009, the [[Metropolitan Police Authority]] decided to publish the original internal police inquiry into Blair Peach's death by the end of the year.<ref>[http://www.mpa.gov.uk/committees/mpa/2009/090625-agm/minutes/?qu=Blair%20Peach&sc=2&ht=1 Minutes of MPA meeting 25 June 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927171604/http://www.mpa.gov.uk/committees/mpa/2009/090625-agm/minutes/?qu=Blair%20Peach&sc=2&ht=1 |date=27 September 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8118748.stm Blair Peach death secrecy review], BBC News, 25 June 2009.</ref> {{as of|2009|December}}, the [[Crown Prosecution Service]] was reviewing the internal report and said it would advise police as to whether further action should be taken.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/8412741.stm|title= CPS to review 1979 protest death|date=14 December 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=14 December 2009}}</ref>
The Cass report into the death of Blair Peach was published by the Metropolitan Police on 27 April 2010. The report concluded that Blair Peach was "almost certainly" killed by one of six SPG officers, some of whom then lied to investigators to cover up the actions of their colleague.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/apr/27/blair-peach-killing-police Blair Peach: After 31 years Met police say 'sorry' for their role in his killing] 27 April 2010</ref> making it impossible to identify the killer.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/apr/27/blair-peach-killed-police-met-report Blair Peach killed by police at 1979 protest, Met report finds] 27 April 2010.</ref>
===Officer E===
The Metropolitan Police report stated that an SPG policeman, identified as Officer E, was “almost certainly” the one whose assault killed Peach.<ref name="Martin Evans The Telegraph">{{cite news|author=Martin Evans |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/7640037/Blair-Peach-Inspector-denies-responsibility.html |title=Blair Peach Inspector denies responsibility|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |date=28 April 2010 |accessdate=17 November 2010| location=London}}</ref> Alan Murray, at the time an inspector in charge of SPG Unit One and now a lecturer in Accounting and Corporate Responsibility at Sheffield University,<ref name="BBC News Police publish report">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8645485.stm |title=Police publish report into death of Blair Peach in 1979|publisher=''[[BBC News]]'' |date=27 April 2010 |accessdate=17 November 2010| location=London}}</ref> has admitted that he believes himself to be Officer E, but has denied killing Peach.<ref name="BBC News Newsnight Suspect">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/newsnight/8299015.stm |title=Blair Peach 'prime suspect' speaks out|publisher=''[[BBC News]]'' |date=27 April 2010 |accessdate=17 November 2010| location=London}}</ref> Murray was described as “young and forceful” by the report, lied to investigators, and refused to participate in identity parades;<ref name="Martin Evans The Telegraph"/>
==Memorials== A primary school in Southall was later named after Blair Peach.<ref>[http://www.ealing.gov.uk/directory_record/86/blair_peach_primary_school Blair Peach Primary School]</ref>
"Reggae Fi Peach", a song on [[Linton Kwesi Johnson]]'s album ''[[Bass Culture]]'', chronicles the death of Blair Peach in the form of [[dub poetry]].<ref>[http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/discography/index.jsp?JSESSIONID=LzhTKTYFWyZLjwxQ2RhfDGzG0jJq5tLTKvSCYg6p9TbgwFXv0vn4!88151879&pid=3410&aid=326052 Billboard]</ref><ref name=SA/> [[The Ruts]] commemorated the death in the tune "Jah War".<ref name=SA>[http://socialistaotearoa.blogspot.com/2009/03/reggae-for-blair-peach-remembering-kiwi.html Reggae for Blair Peach] by Socialist Aoterearoa Organisation blog</ref> The [[2 Tone (music genre)|2 Tone]] album ''The 2 Tone Story'' is dedicated to his memory.<ref name=SA/> [[Hazel O'Connor]] wrote "Calls the Tune" in his memory.<ref name=SA/>
The lyrics to [[The Pop Group]]'s 1980 song "Justice" (from their ''[[For How Much Longer Do We Tolerate Mass Murder?]]'' LP) ask, "Who killed Blair Peach?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wedigdixon.com/pop_group/lyrics.php#justice |title=Pop Group Lyrics |publisher=Wedigdixon.com |date= |accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref>
[[Ralph McTell]] wrote the song "Water of Dreams" in 1982.
[[Chris Searle]] edited ''One for Blair'' in 1989.
The Blair Peach Award was set up by the National Union of Teachers in 2010 to commemorate the former NUT member and as recognition of exemplary work by current members in schools and Union branches for equality and diversity issues.
==See also== *[[Death of Kevin Gately|Kevin Gately]] *[[Death of Ian Tomlinson|Ian Tomlinson]] *[[Liddle Towers]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100502005706/http://www.met.police.uk/foi/units/blair_peach.htm "Investigation into the death of Blair Peach"], ''[[Metropolitan Police Service]]'', 27 April 2010. *Editorial: [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/apr/28/death-of-blair-peach-editorial "Death of Blair Peach: The truth at last"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 28 April 2010. *Paul Lewis, [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/apr/27/thirty-year-fight-report-blair-peach "The 30-year fight to release report into Blair Peach death"], ''The Guardian'', 27 April 2010. *Celia Stubbs, [https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/jun/14/blair-peach-killing-cover-up "Lessons from the death of Blair Peach"], ''The Guardian'', 14 June 2009. *Alison Roberts: [https://www.standard.co.uk/news/i-thought-oh-my-god-its-like-blair-peach-over-again-6908754.html "I thought 'Oh my God, it’s like Blair Peach over again'"], ''[[Evening Standard]]'', 15 April 2009. *David Renton, [http://www.lrb.co.uk/v36/n10/david-renton/the-killing-of-blair-peach "The Killing of Blair Peach"], ''[[London Review of Books]]'', 22 May 2014. *Nick Grant and Brian Richardson, [http://www.bookmarksbookshop.co.uk/view/38055/Blair+Peach+%3A+Socialist+and+Anti-Racist ''Blair Peach: Socialist and Anti-Racist''], London: Socialist Workers' Party, 2014.
==External links== * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/player/nol/newsid_6550000/newsid_6559500/6559545.stm?bw=nb&mp=wm&news=1&bbcws=1 1979: Teacher dies in Southall riots] "A 33-year-old man dies from head injuries after fighting between police and demonstrators in Southall. (First broadcast 23 April 1979)" video of events by [[BBC News]] * [http://socialistworker.co.uk/art/37978/35+years+since+they+murdered+Blair+Peach,+cops+still+get+away+with+murder 35 years since they murdered Blair Peach, cops still get away with murder] *[http://marxists.org/archive/foot-paul/1979/06/blair.html Blair: our brother, our friend] by [[Paul Foot (journalist)|Paul Foot]]
